message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and examination findings suggest Necrotizing enterocolitis, which is common in premature infants and those with formula feeding. The abdominal x-ray also supports the diagnosis with air in the bowel wall or portal vein. The other options are less likely based on the symptoms and examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn has symptoms of feeding difficulty, diarrhea, vomiting, lethargy, abdominal tenderness, and positive test for occult blood, which all suggest the diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis. Meckel diverticulum, hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, and duodenal atresia present with different symptoms and signs. The x-ray also shows pneumatosis intestinalis, which is commonly associated with necrotizing enterocolitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of feeding difficulty, vomiting, diarrhea, and positive occult blood in stool suggest gastrointestinal problem. The x-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis, which in a newborn, is highly suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis. Meckel diverticulum is usually asymptomatic and duodenal atresia presents with bilious vomiting. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is rare in premature infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and exam findings suggest necrotizing enterocolitis, which is common in preterm infants and can be caused by formula feeding. The x-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis, a hallmark finding in necrotizing enterocolitis. Meckel diverticulum, hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, and duodenal atresia are less common in preterm infants and present with different symptoms and exam findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and x-ray findings suggest necrotizing enterocolitis, which is a common gastrointestinal emergency in preterm infants. Meckel diverticulum presents as painless intestinal bleeding, hypertrophic pyloric stenosis presents with projectile vomiting, and duodenal atresia presents with bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and abdominal x-ray are consistent with necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), which is more common in premature infants and can be caused by a combination of factors including bacterial colonization, intestinal immaturity, and enteral feeding. Meckel diverticulum is a possible cause of gastrointestinal bleeding but does not explain the other symptoms. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis and duodenal atresia are less likely given the age and history of the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of difficulty feeding, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal tenderness, absent bowel sounds, positive test for occult blood in stool, and an x-ray of the abdomen showing pneumatosis intestinalis are classic features of necrotizing enterocolitis. Meckel diverticulum usually presents with painless rectal bleeding, while hypertrophic pyloric stenosis and duodenal atresia typically present with projectile vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings suggest that the most likely diagnosis is necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC), which is a serious gastrointestinal disease primarily seen in preterm infants. Although Meckel diverticulum and duodenal atresia can also cause feeding issues in newborns, they are less likely due to the presence of diarrhea and positive stool occult blood. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis typically presents with projectile vomiting and is not associated with bloody diarrhea or abdominal tenderness. The x-ray of the abdomen is consistent with NEC. Immediate treatment is needed to prevent septicemia and death.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings of absent bowel sounds, diffuse abdominal tenderness, rigidity, and guarding with positive occult blood, along with the patient being a premature infant, point towards necrotizing enterocolitis. The x-ray findings also support this diagnosis. Meckel diverticulum and hypertrophic pyloric stenosis are unlikely in a premature infant, and duodenal atresia typically presents with bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and findings of this newborn suggest Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). This includes feeding difficulties, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal distension and tenderness, and absent bowel sounds. The positive occult blood test and low platelet count are also common findings in NEC. The x-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis, which is a radiographic sign for NEC. The other options may present with vomiting and diarrhea, but they do not have the same combination of symptoms and radiographic findings as NEC.
